resources.string: has been pinned to the Launcher
has been unpinned from the Launcher
How wide the Launcher and the icons within it should be. The slider goes from 48dip to 120dip, with the default (right in the middle) being 84dip.
How opaque the background colour of icons in the Launcher should be.
Make the Launcher available inside other apps

When you swipe from the bottom half of the left edge of the screen, the Launcher will appear, allowing you to launch apps which you have pinned to the Launcher without having to go to the home screen.\n(EXPERIMENTAL)

The Launcher will show which apps are currently running. This will be indicated by a small arrow on the left side of the icon. Apps which are running but have not been pinned to the Launcher will also be shown.
Whether the Panel at the top of the screen should be shown or not.
How opaque the Panel should be.

Dynamically pick the background colour of transparent Unity components (Launcher, and the Dash and Panel when the Dash is opened) based on the dominant colour of the wallpaper. This won\'t work when a live wallpaper is set, in which case it will fall back to a transparent black.
The background colour that should be used for transparent Unity components.
Use the sliders to pick a colour.
How opaque the background colour of transparent Unity components should be.
The method that should be used to blur the background when the Dash is opened. When \"Downscale & upscale\" is chosen and it fails (or a live wallpaper is set), \"Darken\" will be used as fallback.
To which screen edge the Launcher should be attached.
Taking more samples greatly increases accuracy but can result in longer loading times on slower devices.

Using HSV (Hue, Saturation, Value) instead of plain RGB (Red, Green, Blue) will result in colours being much more vibrant, but the calculations that are being preformed are more complicated which can result in longer loading times on slower devices.

Enabling this option will result in better Dash search results but will also affect performance on slower devices or devices with a lot of apps installed. If Dash search is slow for you, you might want to consider disabling this.
The Dash will automatically be opened once apps are loaded.
* Testing (If he doesn\'t manage to wreck it then it\'s probably safe for consumption by the rest of the world.)\n * Help with the dominant colour calculation function.
* I used his ProgressWheel component, since the default (round) Android ProgressBar component can\'t actually indicate progress.\n https://github.com/Todd-Davies/ProgressWheel/
* I used his ExpandableHeightGridView component.\n http://stackoverflow.com/a/8483078/521361
* I used his ColorMixer component in the Preferences screen.\n https://github.com/commonsguy/cwac-colormixer
A lot of time and hard work went into the development of this application. If you\'d like to help out, there are several ways in which you can do so.

Ubuntu Launcher is available in several languages. This is because volunteers provide the project with their translations. If Ubuntu Launcher has not been translated yet into your own language, and you understand English (and you have sufficient knowledge of Ubuntu to understand some of the more Unity-related terms), then helping out with translations is a good way to help out. \nTranslations for Ubuntu Launcher are managed on Transifex. All you need to do is request to join a translation team. After that I will approve your request and you are good to go.

If there is a bug in Ubuntu Launcher, that does not necessarily mean that I am aware of its existence. Developers are generally quite bad at testing their own applications as they will only use them in a way they are intended to be used. Some problems also only exist in certain specific circumstances (for example a certain device running a specific version of Android with some extra options enabled). So if you find a bug in Ubuntu Launcher (or if you have a feature request) you can help out by reporting it. \nBugs reports for Ubuntu Launcher are kept on GitHub. If GitHub is too technical for you, you can also just send an e-mail to android-dev@robinj.be. Just make sure it\'s in English or Dutch. Please provide as much (relevant) information as possible.

If you want, you can also make a monetary donation to the developer. Donations are handled via PayPal. You will be able to pick the amount of money you'd like to donate. 
Note: It's a donation. I am not selling anything, and you are not buying anything. Donations are greatly appreciated, but you will not gain any additional features because of it. All features of this application are available free of charge. 
 
PayPal takes a $0.30 + 2.2% fee, so if your donation is less than $0.30 then all of it will go to PayPal, and none of it will reach the developer. If you donate, it's best to make your donation more than this amount, unless for some strange reason you'd like to make a donation to PayPal itself.
